20. The Story of King Prasenajit's Ugly Daughter Lai-ti (20) The Story of King Prasenajit's Ugly Daughter Lai-ti In the past, King Prasenajit had a daughter named Lai-ti, who had eighteen ugly features and did not resemble a human being at all. Those who saw her were all frightened.
At that time, King Prasenajit offered a reward in the country, saying, Whoever has a son from a prominent family, who is poor, orphaned, and alone, I will support him.

At that time, the son of the elder said to the king:

The king then took her as his wife and built a palace for her. He instructed the son of the elder, saying:
This woman is ugly. Be careful not to show her to others. When going out, lock the door. When entering, close the door. Make this a constant rule.

There were sons of elders who were close friends. They drank, feasted, and played together. Whenever there was a gathering, the wives of the sons of the elders all came to the gathering, but only the king's daughter did not come.
Then the people together made an agreement, saying:
On the next day, we will have another gathering. We order you to bring your wife. If you do not come, we will impose a heavy fine.
Again they held a gathering, but the poor son of the elder still did not bring his wife as before. The people then together imposed a heavy penalty on him.
The poor son of the elder respectfully accepted the penalty.
The people again made an agreement, saying:
On the next day, we will have another gathering. If you do not bring your wife, we will impose a heavy penalty again.
Thus punished, up to the second and third time, he still did not bring her to the assembly.
Later, the poor elder's son returned home and said to his wife:
I have been punished several times because of you.
His wife asked why.
Her husband said:
There is an agreement among the people that on the day of the drinking assembly, everyone must bring their wife to the assembly.
Because I was ordered by the king not to bring you to show to outsiders, I have been punished several times.
When his wife heard this, she was greatly ashamed and deeply remorseful. Day and night, she contemplated the Buddha.
On a later day, the husband went to the assembly alone again. His wife, in the inner room, redoubled her sincerity and made a vow, saying:
The TathÄgata's appearance in the world benefits many. I, with my sinful evil, alone do not receive his grace.
The Buddha, moved by her sincerity, emerged from the ground. When she first saw the Buddha's hair, she was overjoyed and her hair immediately changed into beautiful hair.
Next, she saw the Buddha's forehead, gradually seeing his eyebrows, eyes, ears, nose, and mouth. As she saw each part, her joy deepened.
Her body then transformed, and all her ugliness disappeared, her appearance becoming like that of a celestial being.
The elders' sons secretly discussed among themselves:
The reason the princess did not come to the gathering must be that she is exceptionally beautiful,
or perhaps extremely ugly, and that is why she did not come.ğŸ”½We should now encourage her husband to drink until he is unaware, take the key, open the door, and go see for ourselves.

They then made him drunk, took the key, went together to open the door and look. Seeing that the princess was incomparably beautiful, they returned, closed the door, and went back to their original place.
At that time, her husband was still asleep, and he put the key back on his waist.
When the husband woke up, he returned home and opened the door. Seeing his wife's exceptionally beautiful appearance, he was surprised and asked:

The wife said:

The husband was surprised and asked the reason for this sudden change.

22 The Story of Two Brothers, Princes, Who Were Expelled from Their Country (22) The Story of Two Brothers, Princes, Who Were Expelled from Their Country In the past, there were two brothers, princes, who were expelled from their country. He sent people into the water to go and welcome him, and made him king.
The king's former wife carried the maimed man, begging and seeking alms, and arrived in the prince's country.

She replied,

She replied,

The king said,

She looked at the king and then felt ashamed.

The Buddha said:

The wife at that time is the Brahmin woman Chandaka who accused me with a wooden pillow.
